repnme.cdata!:
Trinidad and Tobago - Environmental
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This report downgrades ratings by both
            the Implementation Completion Report, and the Evaluation
            Summary (ES), from satisfactory project outcomes to
            moderately unsatisfactory, sustainability from highly likely
            to likely, and institutional development impacts, from
            substantial to only modest, and, while the Bank performance
            remained equally satisfactory, the performance by the
            Borrower is also downgraded to unsatisfactory. The main
            lessons outline that specific, and monitorable development
            objectives are a strong incentive to effective project
            implementation, particularly when institutional changes are
            substantial parts of the implementation schedule. However,
            justification for Bank involvement in the institutional
            groundwork of such a long-term process as environmental
            management, should be built on a clear understanding between
            the parties, and a commitment by the Bank as to continued
            assistance. Additionally, it is suggested that the
            Environmental Management Authority (EMA) be instituted
            within a neutral part of the government structure, even
            located outside of it, where no real, or perceived conflict
            of interest resulting from its environmental activities, may
            be possible. EMA's decisions should be based on
            technical, and economic considerations alone.

repnme.cdata!:
Trindad and Tobago - Environmental
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Environmental
            Management Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability
            as highly likely, institutional development impact as
            substantial, bank performance as satisfactory, and borrower
            performance as satisfactory. The lessons learned from this
            project include: 1) Although the benefits of stakeholder
            participation are now widely acknowledged, it was
            particularly important for the environmental management
            authority which sought to change the behavior of firms and
            individuals. 2) Public awareness and education are effective
            means of influencing behavioral change toward more
            environmentally sound practices. 3) The Bank should
            disseminate these experiences based on the projects it has
            financed for greater use of team members form other country
            units in supervision missions and in reviewing project
            documents. 4) Environmental management organizations should
            quickly demonstrate their ability to enforce the
            environmental laws which will address some of these
            expectations and engender public confidence. 5) Although it
            is impractical to fully strengthen the legal framework in
            advance, it is often possible to identify key pieces of
            legislation that can affect the project's outcome. Such
            legislations should be passed prior to project
            effectiveness. 6) A good understanding of the local
            political pressures or prevailing policies is important in
            ensuring adjustments in project requirements.

repnme.cdata!:
Trinidad and Tobago - Environmental
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Environmental
            Management Project is to build effective institutional
            capacity to plan and implement sound environmental
            management. Further objectives are to complete a national
            environmental action plan (NEAP), support a priority work
            program which will strengthen the legal and regulatory
            framework, and implement measures for improved environmental
            management consistent with the findings of the NEAP. The
            project will provide for: 1) the purchase of computer
            hardware and software and other office equipment and
            vehichles; 2) about 150 person-months of international and
            local consultants who will prepare a NEAP, provide advice on
            policy, legal and technical matters, and undertake studies
            on priority areas; 3) training workshops, seminars, public
            awareness, curriculum development and environmental
            education; 4) the cost of incremental salaries for staff
            contracted, support for the Environmental Management
            Authority, and the incremental costs associated with support
            of the participating agencies (NGO's, private sector
            agencies, etc.); and 5) operational and overhead materials
            and supplies for the project.
